1.title: Sunset Showdown

episode of.title: Storms of the Great Plains (TV Series 2013– )

1.plot: A long day of storm chasing in Central Kansas pays off with a long rope tornado touching down just as the sun sets. Also featured are Skip Talbot & Caleb Elliott of Wx-Pilot.com, providing a rare aerial perspective of the storm.

13.title: Behind the Scenes, the Making Of

episode of.title: Storms of the Great Plains (TV Series 2013– )

13.plot: Go behind the scenes with the cast and crew of SGP to see just what the teams go through to forecast, shot and edit the show.

imdb.plot outline: STORMS OF THE GREAT PLAINS is an American documentary reality television series that enables the viewer to experience what it's really like to chase severe storms on the Great Plains of the United States. This unique parcel of American real-estate, known as Tornado Alley, boasts the greatest concentration of tornadic activity, more than anywhere else in the world. This half-hour television series places the viewer right in the midst of the action with our teams of seasoned storm chasers as they endeavor to forecast and chase the most violent and dramatic thunderstorms on Earth. 1920 x 1080 high-definition cameras follow these rogue weather enthusiasts as they navigate the back roads of the plains, searching for their next encounter with Mother Nature's untamed fury. Each spring, the chasers analyze the data and carefully position themselves to catch a glimpse of the "storm of the day". Storm chasing is a very demanding and commonly dictates that chasers drive hundreds, even thousands of miles, crisscrossing the Great Plain states, in order to position themselves for the next storm. With chase vehicles equipped with the latest storm tracking technologies, the chasers are able to analyze up to the minute radar and satellite imagery, current observations, in addition to computer forecast models that simulate the atmosphere, depicting both current and upcoming weather patterns. These forecast models are sometimes scrutinized up to a week in advance, and update constantly as the actual day of the storm draws nearer. All of these resources assist the chasers in making the most informed decisions when contemplating which storms to chase.
imdb.title: Storms of the Great Plains
akas: Storms of the Great Plains (United States)
plot: Witness, first-hand, the awesome power of nature's fury, back dropped amongst the timeless beauty of the Great Plains.::Walt VanRheen

STORMS OF THE GREAT PLAINS is an American documentary reality television series that enables the viewer to experience what it's really like to chase severe storms on the Great Plains of the United States. This unique parcel of American real-estate, known as Tornado Alley, boasts the greatest concentration of tornadic activity, more than anywhere else in the world. This half-hour television series places the viewer right in the midst of the action with our teams of seasoned storm chasers as they endeavor to forecast and chase the most violent and dramatic thunderstorms on Earth. 1920 x 1080 high-definition cameras follow these rogue weather enthusiasts as they navigate the back roads of the plains, searching for their next encounter with Mother Nature's untamed fury. Each spring, the chasers analyze the data and carefully position themselves to catch a glimpse of the "storm of the day". Storm chasing is a very demanding and commonly dictates that chasers drive hundreds, even thousands of miles, crisscrossing the Great Plain states, in order to position themselves for the next storm. With chase vehicles equipped with the latest storm tracking technologies, the chasers are able to analyze up to the minute radar and satellite imagery, current observations, in addition to computer forecast models that simulate the atmosphere, depicting both current and upcoming weather patterns. These forecast models are sometimes scrutinized up to a week in advance, and update constantly as the actual day of the storm draws nearer. All of these resources assist the chasers in making the most informed decisions when contemplating which storms to chase.::Walt VanRheen
